Asteroids, Meteors & Impacts

Understanding small bodies and their effects on Earth
← Back to Mission Open Interactive Tool

Overview

Asteroids — sometimes called minor planets — are rocky, airless remnants left over from the early formation of our solar system about 4.6 billion years ago. Most asteroids orbit the Sun in the main belt between Mars and Jupiter. Sizes range from Vesta (~530 km diameter) down to bodies less than 10 meters across. The combined mass of all asteroids is smaller than the Moon.

Near-Earth Objects (NEOs)

Objects (asteroids or comets) whose orbits bring them close to Earth's neighborhood are known as Near-Earth Objects (NEOs). About 99% of NEOs are asteroids. NEOs have perihelion distances less than 1.3 AU (astronomical units).

Potentially Hazardous Asteroids (PHAs)

An asteroid is classified as a Potentially Hazardous Asteroid when its orbit comes within ~7.5 million kilometers of Earth's orbit and its estimated diameter is ≥140 meters. This classification indicates a potential threat, not a guaranteed impact.

Meteors & Meteorites

When small bodies (meteoroids) enter a planet's atmosphere at high speed and disintegrate, they create bright streaks called meteors — colloquially "shooting stars". If a fragment survives atmospheric passage and reaches the ground, it is a meteorite.

Typical Behavior

Most small space rocks (smaller than a football field) disintegrate in the atmosphere. Travelling at tens of thousands of kilometers per hour, they break apart when dynamic pressure exceeds material strength. Usually less than 5% of the original mass reaches the surface.

The "Impactor-2025" Scenario

A newly identified near-Earth object called Impactor-2025 has been flagged as a potential threat. Current orbital solutions warrant monitoring and simulation. Identifying probability, impact energy and likely consequences requires accurate orbital elements, size/mass estimates and entry-angle modeling.

How can we prepare? — Early detection, impact probability assessment, evacuation planning for high-risk zones, and testing mitigation strategies (e.g., deflection) are core measures.

Interactive visualization & simulation tool

We developed an interactive visualization and simulation environment that allows users to:

  • Explore asteroid orbits and visualize orbital trajectories
  • Simulate impact scenarios and estimate energy release and affected area
  • Compare mitigation strategies: kinetic deflection, evacuation footprints, warning times
  • Load or sample real datasets (e.g., NASA / USGS catalogue) for realistic scenarios
Launch Simulation How to use

How to use it

The tool provides intuitive controls: load an object (real or synthetic), adjust size/mass and entry angle, and run the simulation. Interactive maps show projected impact zones and probabilistic damage layers. Use time sliders to view pre- and post-impact scenarios.

What does it help me analyze?

The simulation helps estimate impact energy, crater size, blast overpressure ranges, thermal effects, and likely human/structural exposure. It is a planning and education tool — results depend on input assumptions and should be interpreted with appropriate scientific caution.
